data.title: Russian keyboard layout: hotkeys don't work
data.body:
Can't use some shortcuts while system keyboard layout is not english

- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. change system keyboard language to Russian (for example)
2. use any hotkeys (for example `"key": "cmd+S"`) and you can't save document while you not change shortcut in keybinding.json `"key": "cmd+[KeyS]"`
![2017-04-07 11 52 45](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6111214/24792965/c4c1fc04-1b88-11e7-9ec7-4172131b5bf9.png)

|md2pdf|qinjia|0.0.1|
|dark-win16-theme|rbukovansky|0.0.4|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.5.1|
|swiftlint|shinnn|0.1.3|
|guides|spywhere|0.7.0|
|gitblame|waderyan|1.3.0|
|join-lines|wmaurer|0.2.2|
|markdown-pdf|yzane|0.1.7|
|Material-theme|zhuangtongfa|2.3.9|;

---
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have a Mac with mscOS Sierra
2. Install VSCode and run it
3. Check the screen for different color areas

There are some areas of main window and welcome screen, that are in different color then rest of the same window (some of them are less visible, but they are ther). See attached screenshots (first screenshot -> below Open Folder, second -> areas on the sides of VSCode logo)

![screen shot 2017-04-07 at 10 25 29](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1004491/24792098/ec06bb30-1b7c-11e7-8c62-5f2c993b7f56.png)
![screen shot 2017-04-07 at 10 27 19](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1004491/24792099/ec1f3e76-1b7c-11e7-801d-1abb7eac0b99.png)


I'm able to reproduce that even with stable VSCode with default settings and no extensions installed. Actually screenshots are from it. With different theme they are more visible.
I know it's cosmetic, but it's really distracting...

Thank you.

data.title: Add option to order tabs by file type, then alphabetically
data.body:
I recently switched from Atom to VSCode and so far I'm extremely happy. 

The one feature I miss from Atom (with a plugin) is the possibility to automatically order tabs by filetype first, then alphabetically. 

Combined with color coded tab names it makes it very easy to quickly spot the right tab by first looking for the color of the file type you're looking for and then.

![ordered-tabs](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/345645/24791051/ee5913aa-1b78-11e7-8bc0-635ffc49a78f.png)

It could be added as an open positioning option:
`"workbench.editor.openPositioning": "filetype"`

I couldn't find an extension that would do this, and it seems tab ordering is not possible to extend?

data.title: Merge in translations
Keyboard shortcuts have reversed position of ` and §

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.0/1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

Since updating to VS Code 1.11 I was unable to toggle the integrated terminal. Checking the new keybindings confirmed that the shortcut had not changed from (ctrl + \`). When attempting to re-bind the shortcut, I noticed that this screen has mixed up the position of the \` and  § keys, although in the standard editing window, \` and § are correctly positioned.

1. In the editing window, the \` and § keys behave as normal
2. In the key bindings menu, (attempting to add a new, or change an existing key binding), \` and § are reversed
3. In order to open the integrated terminal, you have to press (ctrl + §), even though the binding is set to (ctrl + \`)

1. Open code
2. Open file with win-1251 encoding (or any other except utf*)
3. Change encoding to correct
4. Type something
5. Close vscode without save
6. Open code again
7. File now is silently convert to utf8

data.title: Intellisense shows "mousewheel" as an applicable event
data.body:
mousewheel should be removed from Javascript's intellisense as it is deprecated and only supported in IE6, Chrome 1, Opera 10, Safari 3, and surprisingly IE Edge. If not removed then it should have "(deprecated)" next to it so people don't accidentally use it instead of "wheel".

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. type "window.addEventListener('mouse..." and notice "mousewheel" as an available option.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Events/mousewheel

data.title: Cycle trough previous searches in 'Go to File' input
data.body:
Recently switched to vscode from Atom and the only thing I miss very much is to easily cycle through previous queries when searching for a specific file using  `Ctrl + P` (or `Ctrl + E`)
Search history is [already implemented](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/5508#issuecomment-246646872) for Search box and Find box. That would be cool to implement something similar also for `Go to File` box

data.title: Blank window on startup (network related?)
data.body:
VS Code worked fine until it self-updated from 1.11.0 to 1.11.1. After the first restart only empty windows appeared and the application hung. After killing Code and Code Helper processes it doesn't start at all. Processes Code and "Code Helper" are running, but no windows are created. Adding `"git.enabled": false` to settings doesn't make any difference. Downgrading to 1.11.0 restores functionality. 

I can provide a hang report of the initial hang after upgrade if necessary.

- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.4

Extensions:

- Java Debugger 0.0.2
- Language Support for Java(TM) by Red Hat 0.1.0
- php cs fixer 0.1.33
- PHP Debug 1.10.0
- PHP Extension Pack 1.0.1
- PHP IntelliSense 1.1.4
- PHP Intellisense - Crane 0.3.6
- phpcs 0.7.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install version 1.11.1
2. Try to execute it

data.title: Dutch keyboard layout: ctrl-` is displayed wrong
data.body:
In the Keyboard Shortcuts window, typing ctrl-` shows up as ctrl+[IntlBackslash], which displays as ctrl-§. I use a Dutch Apple keyboard.

Steps to Reproduce:

Keyboard Shortcuts window. Weirdly, typing ctrl-` shows up as ctrl+[IntlBackslash], which displays as ctrl-§. I use a Dutch keyboard.

1. open the Keyboard Shortcuts window
2. click + in front of a line to open the window where you can enter a shortcut
3. type ctrl-`

- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.0 (9122ec4b1068bd391e41974f46a4b54c1b9c90f9, 2017-04-05T20:52:01.201Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0
- no extensions

data.title: `this` is undefined on debug mode
Saving the code is not formatting anymore in 1.11.0/1
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan (10.11.2)

In previous version, when I saved the file (cmnd+s) automagically fixed the formatting for me, but it is not happening anymore.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install VSCode 1.11.1 on OS X 10.11.2 
2. Create a code without formatting
```
  tag {
    key     = "terraform"
    value          = true
    propagate_at_launch = true
  }
```
3. Try Saving the file (cmnd+s)

data.title: Arch Linux / Fedora: Reading keyboard layout reads the wrong one

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Since version 1.11.1 (last I used was 1.10.2), the shortcut to "Toggle Line Comment" (which was `Ctrl+/`) now zooms out, like when pressing (`Ctrl+-`). Pressing `Ctrl+Shift+7` does work, but `Shift+7` is `&`. The actual layout when writing text, is correctly set to US, but shortcuts are interpreted as DE.  

- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: Arch Linux 64-bit (using the .tar.gz version)
- Desktop environment: KDE Plasma 5.9
- Current keyboard layout: EN-US

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open Keyboard Shortcuts.
2. Find the shortcut and edit it.

Inside [`Developer: Inspect Key Mappings`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/Keybindings#troubleshooting-2-command---what-key-to-press) there is no `VK_OEM_2`.

Some interesting values:
```
Layout info:
{
	"model": "pc104",
	"layout": "de,us",
	"variant": "",
	"options": "grp:win_space_toggle,kpdl:dotoss,altwin:meta_alt,caps:ctrl_modifier",
	"rules": "evdev"
}
isUSStandard: false
```
```
	"Minus": {
		"value": "ß",
		"withShift": "?",
		"withAltGr": "\\",
		"withShiftAltGr": "¿"
	},
```
```
	"Slash": {
		"value": "-",
		"withShift": "_",
		"withAltGr": "–",
		"withShiftAltGr": "—"
	},
```

The issue seems to be that when there are multiple layouts configured, VS Code sets as key layout the first value for `layout` form `setxkbmap -query`, ignoring the current layout. If I switch to be `en,de` then VS Code uses the EN layout, as it is the first in the list. It would be handy if VS Code could use the current layout instead of the first from the list.
